title: What are the beliefs of Friedrich Nietzsche? - Quora

response.answer_text: First of all, I must take issue with your word “beliefs,” since Nietzsche was not a philosopher whose ideas could be briefly summarized. As with all great men and thinkers, there runs through Nietzsche’s thought and life deep spiritual anxiety— and one of the highest order. But, despite and perhaps because of these contradictions, he was certainly the most important philosopher of our Age. It would be naive to think that to study his thought is a “historical” enterprise. To speak of him is to refer to Burkhardt, Wittgenstein, Jaspers, Marcel, Heidegger, Husserl, Camus, and Sartre among others. All of them lived and struggled with a world that had been enunciated and foreseen by Nietzsche, and all of their attempts at a new basis for philosophy is in large measure commentary on Nietzsche, and an attempt to respond to the profound, paradoxical and nihilistic issues he recognized in Western Philosophy. Instead of providing a seriatim of his “beliefs” or “quotes” which would necessarily be an oversimplification of his thoughts, importance and the issues with which he “fought,” I will try to elucidate some aspects of his “philosophy” and his “life”—which is simply another way of saying that who Nietzsche was, and what he wrote, with all of his contradictions, in many ways reflected each other and all of their inherent ambiguities. Given this “foreword,” which I must acknowledge is much too limited for a discussion of such a philosopher, I have chosen to elucidate what I believe to be some of his most significant philosophical insights and themes and those aspects of his life with which he wrestled because of, and in spite of his insights. To begin with: Nietzsche saw that the “highest values” had begun to “devalue themselves.” He dramatically characterized this devaluation of values, and hence our life, with his resounding and provocative statement that “God is dead.” (No statement by any philosopher has been so universally quoted, and so misunderstood, as this statement.) He was correct in his analysis that, before him, there had been no suspicion that there was anything problematic about morality. For instance, Nietzsche brought to the modern mind that the Christian value of truth-telling, institutionalized in the form of science, had paradoxically undermined the belief in God, disenchanting man with the world and excluding his soul from a pre-established harmony between the nature of the world and man’s mind, desires, and dreams and that the evaporation of a morality or sense of worth inherent in the world, an a priori bond between man’s value and meaning, between morality and truth, was henceforth invalid. And, thus he took it upon himself to expose these lies. But it would be insufficient to say that Nietzsche merely recognized the catastrophic result of this devaluation—this severance of man and morality, and his place in the world—that would inevitably crush man who would fall victim to despair in the face of nihilism, and the recognition that life has no intrinsic value or meaning. Until Nietzsche exposed this moral catastrophe, or catastrophe of morality, the connection between the nature of man’s soul and his place in the world had supplied man both with an unassailable morality and human value that grounded man’s firm place in the world created by God. Thus, Nietzsche was the first philosopher to recognize the profound depth and consequences of the sickness of this Age: nihilism. (Of course, this phrase immediately makes one think of Kierkegaard and his thoughts on the nature of the “mass man.” He wrestled with many similar issues as Nietzsche and anticipates many of the thinkers I previously mentioned, perhaps most importantly Marcuse.) But, many have misinterpreted Nietzsche's thought as if his focus on “nihilism” was a moral license for any type of conduct, merely a reference to a “strong” or creative individual, someone who could take responsibility for his own meaning, or one who could live by a subjective morality by “transvaluing” the highest values by establishing a new “order of rank.” But this analysis completely misses the point. He dreaded the new age of nihilism which he was compelled to bring into being. And he saw huge world wars that would be fought after he was gone, all in the name of ideology—and he was not wrong. As a creator, facing the gaping abyss which opened after he had crushed the morality his contemporaries believed still existed, he was faced with the agonizing question: “how could morality be judged in the absence of a divine source?” In this regard, one of his most important insights was the recognition that the fractures in Western Metaphysics required man to reestablish morality on a new foundation. And left with the only source that he believed could still provide such a basis: “The question,” he asked, “is how far opinion is life furthering, life-preserving, species-preserving, perhaps species-rearing, and we are fundamentally inclined to maintain that the falsest opinions (to which the synthetic judgments a priori belong) are the most indispensable to us, that without a recognition of logical fictions, without a comparison of reality with the purely IMAGINED world of the absolute and immutable, without a constant counterfeiting of the world by means of numbers, man could not live—that the renunciation of false opinions would be a renunciation of life, a negation of life. TO RECOGNISE UNTRUTH AS A CONDITION OF LIFE; that is certainly to impugn the traditional ideas of value in a dangerous manner, and a philosophy which ventures to do so, has thereby alone placed itself beyond good and evil.” Thus, the essence of such a venture to confront nihilism was to “philosophize with a hammer,” as he put it, to undermine what was undeniably false and destructive to man—the recognition that nihilism already existed in Western Philosophy. Nietzsche did not “invent” nihilism—though he did coin the term, he recognized that it had already appeared on the philosophical stage and that the philosophical efforts during the 19th Century could all be considered furious attempts to avoid this truth. Most interpretations—and interpreters—of Nietzsche completely misunderstand his relationship with morality and truth. In so many descriptions of Nietzsche, he is characterized as being an aberration in the Western tradition, believing him to have been a destroyer ushering in a time of chaos and amorality. This description completely misses Nietzsche the creator, a man who despaired over the loss of pre-established harmony with which man had understood his place in the world, and who tendentiously proposed the “Eternal Recurrence” (to live as if one would live that same life over and over), and the “Ubermensch,” a new type of man who could rise above conventional Christian morality to create and impose his own values as perhaps the only spiritual cures. [Thus Spake Zarathustra (1883–85).] But there is no question that Nietzsche as psychologist, in his role as destroyer of outmoded and hence destructive lies passing themselves off as truth: Nietzsche states: “who knows if they are not really trying to win back something which was formerly an even securer possession, something of the old domain of the faith of former times, perhaps the ‘immortal soul,’ perhaps ‘the old God,’ in short, ideas by which they could live better, that is to say, more vigorously and more joyously than by ‘modern ideas’?” Or, speaking to those who would embrace valuelessness as a credo for life, he said, “You desire to LIVE ‘according to Nature’? Oh, you noble Stoics, what fraud of words! Imagine to yourselves a being like Nature, boundlessly extravagant, boundlessly indifferent, without purpose or consideration, without pity or justice, at once fruitful and barren and uncertain: imagine to yourselves INDIFFERENCE as a power—how COULD you live in accordance with such indifference?” Thus, Nietzsche recognized that his challenge was two-fold, one which I have already discussed, the destruction of a priori metaphysics, the untruth which is presented and the morality that it half-heartedly supported. This is the key to Nietzsche’s attack on truth and morality—they had always supported each other. The strength of Morality, Nietzsche recognized, had been, since Plato, the inversion of morality—the belief that truth was the basis of morality—and that morality of life and life-affirmation had never been attempted. Perhaps a more simple way to describe this is that the Greek, that is to say, the Socratic, notion of morality was that if one “knew” the truth, one would necessarily follow it. But in the 2000 years since Socrates, the purely absolute truth (a priori metaphysics—a truth beyond our existence and fundamentally beyond the mind of man) had never been found, nor could it. The abolition of this conception of morality was for Nietzsche was a necessity and a “morally” required purpose. Nietzsche realized that, until false, outmoded, and questionable conceptions of morality had been destroyed, the ground could not be cleared for something stronger, deeper, and life-affirming. To accomplish this, Nietzsche’s fundamental idea or recognition is that ‘God is dead’—and the resulting nihilism which ensues. As he stated, providing a fairly accurate description of this Age: “Existence has no goal. Deep down: not knowing what is valuable; what is there left? intoxication: the attempt to overcome it by intoxication; intoxication as music, intoxication with cruelty; all purely moral demands without their religious basis must needs end in nihilism; or some sort of mysticism, art for art’s sake, truth for truth's sake, narcotics against self-disgust; some kind of routine, any routine, blatant fanaticism, but none of these drugs can have any lasting effect; he who no longer finds what is great in God, will find it nowhere—he must either deny or create it.” And thus we hear the despair Nietzsche felt at the core of his being. He was attempting to fight two battles at the same time, for and against himself, and so one must ask with him, what can exist after the death of God, what is there left to create? Is there any cure? And, if there is a spiritual cure, whether goodness, innocence, saintliness or self-sacrifice, “would [it] nevertheless be interpreted as a compensatory maneuver of the mind to ‘transvalue’ weakness and frustration?” “The trouble,” he recognized in one of his more profound observations: “is that there can no longer be such virtues. For virtues are reflected upon by minds, and even the purest virtue will be suspect to a mind filled with suspicion.” Nietzsche, like the physician who exposed the patient to the disease, yet had to cure him without having the antidote. This is partly what I mean when I say that he and his thought was a paradox and that this is the reason why he and his philosophy are so often misunderstood or ignored by “modern” thinkers who believe that his observations are easily or, more mendaciously or pitifully, have been overcome by materialism, abstraction or self-referential, empty reflections about something or other, but not about existence, and not about the struggle to live an authentic life. Yes, even here Nietzsche recognized the paradox in the title of his last book: “Twilight of the Idols: How one becomes who one is.” And, indeed, he recognized the inevitable conflict between being and becoming—almost as if he could not, even at the end, escape the whirlwind of his mind. He was unquestionably a truly great psychologist—and he often used it to strip away the veneer of outmoded and destructive morality. (He rightly called himself “the first psychologist.”) Without question, many of his most powerful writings attack the insipid morals and virtues of his day, including their source, that God no longer held sway on man, and thus had to be destroyed because such beliefs were inauthentic and false, indeed, had led man to nihilism. Man’s false beliefs were spiritually and morally destructive. Nietzsche, the psychologist, went even further (and to him, we owe a great deal, and may curse him as well), since man’s nihilism would certainly bring about his spiritual destruction from disillusionment and frustration. And, once he opened the gaping abyss, he could not close it: he repeatedly asked how will man live in this Nihilistic Age? He first tried to use a negative path: “man would despise his former self for craving moral sanctions, for satisfying his will to power in neurotic sublimation, for deceiving himself about the “meaning” of life, and what will such a man be, who at last knows what life really is?” Nietzsche’s personal account of such a man and his all-too-human nature, his analysis of the threadbare fabric of traditional values and truths, might he not be a monster, a barbarian, a conqueror of the world, shrieking bad German from under his dark mustache? Nietzsche (and Dostoevsky, in The Brothers Karamazov, Ivan) very much feared this result though this did not—nor perhaps could not—stop him. He believed firmly that nihilism was the reality of this Age, and that his passion for the truth required the destruction of the lies of the past. He realized that he was ushering in a period which could destroy itself from nihilism or truth, and would bring man to the edge of a terrible truth, but at least to truth. He was often filled with terror of the coming age—our age—in which a vulgar caricature of people would come to power—not in any type of democracy, but in a dictatorship since man could no longer trust or value himself, that he or anyone else could make any moral or even intelligent decisions—at least rational decisions—because he no longer believed in or knew the truth—and so man would hide himself in the mob if only to be part of something. On the other hand, Nietzsche recognized that, in the coming age of nihilism, man would need a “cure” or he would suffer self-destruction. In one of his notebooks, he wrote: “I perform the great experiment: who can bear the idea of the Eternal Recurrence?” (The substance of this quote appears in “Thus Spake Z.”) This, I believe was an expression of a painful measure of Nietzsche’s recognition of the barren world he saw stretching out ahead of him. The Eternal Recurrence was the nightmare of nightmares to him—the idea that to live according to that concept, to live his life again and again was a truly painful thought: as he wrote: “Let us consider this idea in its most terrifying form: existence, as it is, without meaning or goal, but inescapably recurrent, without a finale into nothingness… those who can not bear the sentence there is no salvation, we ought to perish!” Obviously, the Eternal Recurrence was, in truth, a “moral exercise.” Live as if you would live your life again. Could meaning grow from such a principle? It is, I believe, not unsurprising that Nietzsche recognized that, even as a “moral principle” to live by, at its core, was the recognition that such a life was unbearable. From a larger perspective, he also knew the dreadful future for man after he could no longer feel anything spiritual in his life: that those who were sensitive to this loss would be overrun by the worst and their gluttonous machines of death. The essence of all Nietzsche’s philosophy may be that God is Dead, but it is also that man has not yet come to the point of understanding or appreciating this fact—even if he no longer believes in God—and, if God is indeed no more, then for Nietzsche man was an eternally cheated misfit, “the diseased animal” as he called him, “plagued by a metaphysical hunger which was now impossible to feed even if all the Heavens were to be ransacked. Such a creature was doomed: he had to die out, giving way to the superman who would miraculously feed on barren fields and finally conquer the metaphysical hunger itself without any detriment to the glory of life.” Earlier in his life, he wrote The Birth of Tragedy (out of the spirit of music), and, in my opinion, Nietzsche’s prose and passion of that book expressed that transfiguration of life in lasting images of true beauty could overcome meaningless chaos. And though this was a short period in his life during which he was enraptured by Richard Wagner, it ended quickly when Nietzsche realized that Wagner was, according to him “no more than a petty Romantic who sought the goal of life in the beyond.” Nietzsche later chastised himself for what he called his degradation. In his analysis of this period of his life, he stated that the: “belief in art turned to skepticism and scorn; and his anger was provoked by those ‘metaphysical counterfeiters’”, as he called them, “who enthroned the trinity of beauty, goodness, and truth.” In the paradoxical mind of Nietzsche—the essential aspect of understanding him—he contradicted his numerous battles with art, saying: “We have art in order not to perish of Truth,” and, in Zarathustra, “poets lie too much”, but adds “But Zarathustra too is a poet .. We lie too much.” And perhaps he did, because, at the same time that Zarathustra preached the Eternal Recurrence, Nietzsche wrote: “I do not wish to live again. How have I borne life? By creating. What has made me endure? The vision of the Superman who affirms life? I have tried to affirm life myself—but ah!” This could not be more telling. He chose to fight against his mind, and his mind fought against life. Was he, having lost his bond, his salvation in the oneness of God, truly capable of believing in anything? I come back to another of his most quoted statements, in which he said: “He who no longer finds what is great in God will find it nowhere—he must either deny it or create it.” Not many people quote, or perhaps even read or consider this trenchant comment. Nietzsche often doubted himself to the point of despair—so often did he regret his destruction of, or at least unmasking of morality. One could say, it had to be done, and one could also say that the quote ends on a positive note—greatness, and meaning could be created. Nietzsche was, indeed, a paradox, he had a passion for truth and no belief in it. He had the love of life and despaired of it. A few years before he lost his grasp on life in 1889, he wrote: “My life is now comprised of the wish that the truth about all things be different from my way of seeing it: if only someone could convince me of the improbability of my truths.” And another, “Lonely and deeply suspicious of myself as I was, I took, not without secret spite, sides against myself and for anything that happened to hurt me and was hard for me.” But what was he suspicious of? When he was terrified by the prospect that all the better things in life, all honesty of mind, integrity of character, generosity of heart, and fineness of aesthetic perception, would be corrupted and finally cast away by the new barbarians unless the mildest and gentlest hardened themselves for the war which was about to be waged against them: “Caesar—with the heart of Christ!” But perhaps he was not truly a rebel, the destroyer of God and man during his life. A very close mentor and friend once commented on what, infrequently, Nietzsche’s tormented mind called his “Rosengeruch des Unwiederbringlichen,” which he said, of course, was untranslatable, but that the closest translation he believed was Yeat’s lines: “Man is in love and loves what vanishes. What more is there to say?” But despite what so many commentators have written—and aren’t there only commentators now?—Nietzsche was perhaps a traditionalist by heart, a desperate lover who castigated what he loved because he knew it was true and even should truth abandon him and the world. One of my favorite quotes of his was written late in his life: “I once saw a storm raging over the sea, and a clear blue sky above it; it was then that I came to dislike all sunless, cloudy passions which know no light, except the lightning.” And yet this was written by the same man who said that his tool for philosophizing was “a hammer,” and of himself that “he was not human but dynamite.” About the message that he brought to man, namely, that God is dead, he stated: “Perhaps the best will be driven to despair by it, the very worst accept it?” Above all, this was perhaps his greatest doubt and greatest fear—that the hopes he felt when destroying the last vestiges of decaying morality: that man could forever be free of his shackles, and could embrace freedom not known before, was in fact impossible. In this respect, as in so many others, he was a paradox—and is not this Age itself a paradox? He may have brought about the very opposite of what he desired. When this terror overcame him, he was terrified of the world he helped to bring, the consequences of his teaching. But, what Nietzsche may mean for this Age, what he could not embrace: this poet, lover of truth, hater of truth, destroyer, creator, lover of life, and one who despaired of it, a man who resolved to seek out the truth at any cost, and the soul of a redeemer who believed that “only one who has learned to live without truth and without belief and delighting in life actually wills the Eternal Recurrence: Live in such a way that you desire nothing more than to live this very same life again and again.”

Friedrich believes in the Overman. He thinks humanity is wonderful the way it is as it is a rope between the beast and the overman, i.e. a transitory stage which should be appreciated. However, man should strive to become an overman. The overman is someone who has overcome themselves and has achieved their supreme form. The overmen have developed both their thinking and their feeling sides; and their bodies, minds, and souls. They have very strong personalities and do not make compromises with the weaknesses of the rest. He also believes that people should go beyond good and evil. The contemporary morality (which has been the same in the last few thousand years) is the morality of the weak. They use their weakness as a weapon to chain the strong and brave ones. The world needs new values and the overman's purpose is to be the creator of such values. Furthermore, he loves this life and this world. He is against the idea that this world is less important because it's transitory. He believes that humans should appreciate and enjoy everything Earth has given them instead of being modest and feeling small and guilty. Briefly said, Friedrich believes in the supreme, in humanity, in power, strength, boldness, true joyfulness, true suffering, improvement and in the future.
